description.summary: An aggressively direct creature that charges straight at anyone it encounters, attacking head-on without hesitation or strategy.
description.full: The Come-at-a-Body is a fearsome critter notable for its straightforward and aggressive behavior. True to its name, this creature comes directly at anyone it sees, charging head-on with no subtlety or cunning. Unlike stealthy predators or ambush hunters, the Come-at-a-Body's defining characteristic is its direct, relentless charge straight toward victims. According to lumberjack tall tales, there's no hiding from or outsmarting this creatureâ€”it simply comes directly at you. The name itself is dialectical, using 'body' to mean 'person' in the manner of old English or Scottish speech. The Come-at-a-Body represents the fearsome critter tradition's more menacing side, though the creature's absolute lack of subtlety adds dark humor to its threat.

etymology.meaning: 'Come at a body' - dialectical for 'comes at a person'; directly attacks

physical.morphology: Details vary; defined by behavior rather than appearance

abilities.description: Charges straight at targets without deviation

origins.cultural_roots: American occupational folklore from lumber camps
origins.folklore_connections: Dialectical naming; represents direct threat with dark humor

folklore.beliefs: Represented unavoidable danger; threat that cannot be outsmarted

literature: Fearsome Creatures of the Lumberwoods by William T. Cox (1910)
